I am still reeling from shock of how horribly myself and my family were treated. I, visibly pregnant, was seated at a table with a bench on one side and 2 chairs on the other. My 2yo and 5yo were both sitting with me on the bench side waiting for my husband to arrive. There were 3 other similar tables next to us, all still unseated. The hostess kindly brought us crayons for my children to color on the paper laid across the table. My daughter was coloring, never straying once from our table. My son was guardian of the crayons. On three occasions, my *near 2yo* screamed loudly "MINE!" when my daughter went for a crayon. I am well aware this is less than ideal. It is a phase he is in, screeching any time he is excited or mad or expressing emotions. Before and after each of those moments, he was calm and happy and just fine. Each time he did it, I did my best to get him to stop immediately. We had been there all but 10 minutes. The manager, Christopher Fischbach, approached me and said "You are going to have to reign this in." I asked "excuse me?" And he said "you are going to have to reign this in. We can't have your children running around and the screaming will have to stop." I replied that my daughter hadn't left the table once and then asked how he suggest I stop my not yet 2yo son from screaming?" He said he didn't know. I asked "and what if I can't? Will we be escorted out?" And he said "if it is excessive, maybe so. We have to seat these other tables."At this point I was so incredulous, I could not believe this was being said to a paying customer, let alone the fact that a child was being targeted. I asked if this was routine for them, he did not reply and he walked away. I still cannot believe this happened. I am appalled. I am ashamed to say that we stayed, but I refuse to be bullied. Yeah, they got my money, but I have my dignity. And I hope Christopher (who, no, does not have children of his own) treats families trying their absolute best with the respect they deserve moving forward. He was a pretty massive disappointment to humanity tonight.Do yourself a favor and don't waste your money here. The food was not remotely worth what they lack entirely in service.

We planned our meal two months in advance, reserved a table, and hoped to top off the last night of our Seattle vacation with an excellent view, meal and drinks.We were seated on the patio, jammed into a corner but jutting out into the walkway, where we were jostled by staff and other diners. We ordered sodas while taking a moment to look at the wine menu, and decided to share an order of the calamari with spinach. This was okay, a bit overcooked and chewy, but we had high hopes for the meal - I ordered linguine with clams, and my husband ordered clams and mussels.I had one bite of my pasta with clams, and couldn't eat anymore. The pasta was overcooked, but all of that was masked by the amount of sodium in the "broth" - you could taste nothing BUT salt, as though a cup of it had been poured into the cooking liquid. The acidity burned my tongue and scoured the inside of my mouth. I couldn't taste or eat properly for two days afterward. My husband's clams and mussels had no seasoning or taste, other than that of steamed and overcooked seafood. No garlic, wine, herbs or anything else. It was as if they'd steamed the shellfish and dumped them in the bowl. Also, no pasta or other sides were served with that dish: $26 or so for a bowl of flavorless steamed mussels and clams. We declined to order something else, and asked for our check. This was the only time in our lives that we've ever walked out of a restaurant. Although the manager comped our soda and calamari, we left a comparable amount on the table for the waitress and staff. We figured they shouldn't be left without the tip they'd have received had the chef and kitchen staff not put out such an embarassing "meal". We spent an hour trying to find another restaurant that was open in the area after 9 PM, which oddly enough is not easy to do, especially as we'd walked from our rental to The Pink Door.As far as ambience and staff: the greeter and our waitress were very nice. The place was okay, but other than some cute decoration and a good band, it wasn't exceptional - certainly not enough to balance out the mediocre starter and inedible meal. I can honestly say I'd not recommend this restaurant to anyone.

The bartender was very friendly and made me laugh as we chatted about San Francisco, my hometown. The ambiance was charming, with a dark yet cozy interior and live music, which was a lovely bonus.Fast forward to my second visit, which was during my birthday weekend on a solo trip to Seattle. I decided to have my birthday dinner at The Pink Door. Unfortunately, this experience was vastly different. I arrived around 8 PM, close to the last call for dinner, so the restaurant was quite empty. Despite this, the host insisted I sit at the bar again, which felt odd since there were plenty of empty tables and I wanted a more traditional dining experience for my birthday. I ordered an orange cocktail (can't remember the name), and while the waitress carded me, she didn't acknowledge my birthday at all. Additionally, my water cup was only refilled by a passing busser rather than my waitress, who seemed inattentive. The lasagna was just as delicious as before, but the service this time was extremely disappointing. It felt like they weren't interested in providing good service during the last call.The food at The Pink Door is amazing, but the service can be hit or miss. They definitely need to improve their service, especially for customers who dine during quieter times.

I recently had the pleasure of dining at The Pink Door, an Italian restaurant nestled in a charming corner of the city. While my experience had its highlights, there were a few aspects that left me wanting more.Let's start with the positives. The service at The Pink Door was exemplary. From the moment I stepped through the pink-hued entrance, the staff greeted me with warm smiles and made me feel welcome. They were attentive, knowledgeable, and ensured that my dining experience was smooth and enjoyable. Kudos to the staff for their exceptional service!The drink selection at The Pink Door was a true delight. The bar is well-stocked and the mixologists behind it know their craft. I tried a couple of their signature cocktails, and each one was expertly crafted, bursting with unique flavors and beautifully presented. If you're a fan of creative libations, The Pink Door will not disappoint.Now, onto the food. While the dishes at The Pink Door were undeniably well-prepared, I found them to be on the pricier side. It's true that quality ingredients and a skilled culinary team come at a cost, but I couldn't help but feel that the prices were a tad steep for what was served.Specifically, the pasta, often hailed as an Italian staple, left me somewhat underwhelmed. While it was cooked to a perfect al dente texture, the flavors fell slightly short of my expectations. The dishes lacked that extra oomph that elevates a good pasta to a memorable one. Perhaps a bit more attention to seasoning and innovative flavor combinations would enhance the overall dining experience.Despite these shortcomings, The Pink Door does possess its fair share of merits. The attentive service and the remarkable drinks are definite highlights that shouldn't be overlooked. However, I would encourage the restaurant to refine their flavors and consider adjusting their pricing to offer better value for the culinary experience they aim to provide.In summary, The Pink Door is a decent Italian restaurant with good service and amazing drinks. While the food may be a bit expensive and the pasta lacks a little bit of flavor, it's still a place worth visiting if you're in the mood for a charming atmosphere and attentive service.

Nestled in the heart of Seattle, The Pink Door is a true gem among Italian restaurants. From the moment you step inside, you're greeted with the comforting aroma of fresh herbs and garlic, instantly transporting you to a cozy yet elegant, restaurant with perfect setting for a romantic dinner or a gathering with friends.The menu is a culinary journey through Italy, featuring authentic dishes bursting with flavor and made with the finest ingredients. Start your meal with the three meatballs or a delightful selection of cured meats, cheeses, and marinated vegetables. For the main course, the homemade pasta dishes are a must-try, especially the Pink Door lasagna. Each bite is a revelation, showcasing the skill and passion of the chefs.Pair your meal with a glass of wine from their extensive selection, expertly curated to complement the flavors of the food. Our waiter kept bringing us endless amounts of fresh bread with basil infused olive oil and balsamic. Don't forget to save room for dessert! I had the grapefruit marmalade cake with ginger whipped cream.But what truly sets The Pink Door apart is the impeccable service. The staff goes above and beyond to ensure that every guest feels welcome and cared for, adding a personal touch to the dining experience. Thank you Dan for being our waiter this afternoon!In conclusion, The Pink Door is a culinary masterpiece, offering an unforgettable taste of Italy right in the heart of Seattle. Whether you're a seasoned foodie or simply craving authentic Italian cuisine, this restaurant is sure to exceed your expectations. Buon appetito!

We planned our meal two months in advance, reserved a table, and hoped to top off the last night of our Seattle vacation with an excellent view, meal and drinks.We were seated on the patio, jammed into a corner but jutting out into the walkway, where we were jostled by staff and other diners. We ordered sodas while taking a moment to look at the wine menu, and decided to share an order of the calamari with spinach. This was okay, a bit overcooked and chewy, but we had high hopes for the meal - I ordered linguine with clams, and my husband ordered clams and mussels.I had one bite of my pasta with clams, and couldn't eat anymore. The pasta was overcooked, but all of that was masked by the amount of sodium in the "broth" - you could taste nothing BUT salt, as though a cup of it had been poured into the cooking liquid. The acidity burned my tongue and scoured the inside of my mouth. I couldn't taste or eat properly for two days afterward. My husband's clams and mussels had no seasoning or taste, other than that of steamed and overcooked seafood. No garlic, wine, herbs or anything else. It was as if they'd steamed the shellfish and dumped them in the bowl. Also, no pasta or other sides were served with that dish: $26 or so for a bowl of flavorless steamed mussels and clams. We declined to order something else, and asked for our check. This was the only time in our lives that we've ever walked out of a restaurant. Although the manager comped our soda and calamari, we left a comparable amount on the table for the waitress and staff. We figured they shouldn't be left without the tip they'd have received had the chef and kitchen staff not put out such an embarassing "meal". We spent an hour trying to find another restaurant that was open in the area after 9 PM, which oddly enough is not easy to do, especially as we'd walked from our rental to The Pink Door.As far as ambience and staff: the greeter and our waitress were very nice. The place was okay, but other than some cute decoration and a good band, it wasn't exceptional - certainly not enough to balance out the mediocre starter and inedible meal. I can honestly say I'd not recommend this restaurant to anyone.

I recently had the pleasure of dining at The Pink Door, an Italian restaurant nestled in a charming corner of the city. While my experience had its highlights, there were a few aspects that left me wanting more.Let's start with the positives. The service at The Pink Door was exemplary. From the moment I stepped through the pink-hued entrance, the staff greeted me with warm smiles and made me feel welcome. They were attentive, knowledgeable, and ensured that my dining experience was smooth and enjoyable. Kudos to the staff for their exceptional service!The drink selection at The Pink Door was a true delight. The bar is well-stocked and the mixologists behind it know their craft. I tried a couple of their signature cocktails, and each one was expertly crafted, bursting with unique flavors and beautifully presented. If you're a fan of creative libations, The Pink Door will not disappoint.Now, onto the food. While the dishes at The Pink Door were undeniably well-prepared, I found them to be on the pricier side. It's true that quality ingredients and a skilled culinary team come at a cost, but I couldn't help but feel that the prices were a tad steep for what was served.Specifically, the pasta, often hailed as an Italian staple, left me somewhat underwhelmed. While it was cooked to a perfect al dente texture, the flavors fell slightly short of my expectations. The dishes lacked that extra oomph that elevates a good pasta to a memorable one. Perhaps a bit more attention to seasoning and innovative flavor combinations would enhance the overall dining experience.Despite these shortcomings, The Pink Door does possess its fair share of merits. The attentive service and the remarkable drinks are definite highlights that shouldn't be overlooked. However, I would encourage the restaurant to refine their flavors and consider adjusting their pricing to offer better value for the culinary experience they aim to provide.In summary, The Pink Door is a decent Italian restaurant with good service and amazing drinks. While the food may be a bit expensive and the pasta lacks a little bit of flavor, it's still a place worth visiting if you're in the mood for a charming atmosphere and attentive service.

My family and I recently visited The Pink Door and had an incredible dining experience. We ordered two dishes, the Squid Ink Tonnarelli and the Lasagna Pink Door, and both were outstanding. The Squid Ink Tonnarelli was perfectly cooked and had a deliciously unique flavor. The pasta was infused with squid ink, which gave it a slightly briny taste that complemented the breadcrumbs in the dish. The Lasagna Pink Door was equally impressive. It was layered with rich, Bolognese sauce and creamy, making every bite melt in my mouth. We also ordered the Brussels sprouts side dish, which was a standout in its own right. The sprouts were roasted to perfection with a slightly crispy exterior, and the addition of bacon and balsamic vinegar added a wonderful depth of flavor. It was the perfect side dish to accompany our mains. To accompany our meal, we ordered the It Feels Right cocktail and The Pink Door mocktail, both of which were delicious and complemented our dishes perfectly. The It Feels Right cocktail was a refreshing blend of spirits and fruit juices, while The Pink Door mocktail was light and refreshing, making them the perfect complement to our rich and flavorful dishes.The atmosphere of the restaurant was charming and cozy, with the decor adding to the ambiance. Service was impeccable too - our server was attentive and knowledgeable about the menu. Overall, I highly recommend The Pink Door for a special dining experience. I just wanted to post about our recent experience at The Pink Door. Its our wedding anniversary. I checked out a bunch of restaurants ahead of time and decided on The Pink Door due to it's combination of romantic decor, reasonable price and great food reviews.I was mildly worried about some of the comments regarding rude servers and such but figured it was still the best bet in town.After a long day running all over the Pike Place market, we arrived for dinner at 6:30. We were promptly seated and for the life of me can't remember our waiters name. He was extremely polite and had the specials down pat. I ended up ordering the spinach lasagna while my husband had the spaghetti and meatballs. Our food arrived in a reasonable amount of time and we began to enjoy our meal.After just a few bites, a busser working near our table dropped a water glass which shattered all over the floor. As far as we could tell, none of it hit us or the table next to us so we continued our meal. Almost immediately another female employee came up and asked us if we were ok and if any glass had gotten in our food. We told her that it didn't but she insisted on having the food remade just in case. We told her we understood and she removed the old food. Our waiter showed up at the same time and was also concerned about our welfare.A short while later our new food arrived and everything was great. When we went to pay, our waiter brought the check and explained that both our entrees were on the house due to the accident. I told him that wasn't necessary but was greatly appreciated.I just wanted to say a special thanks to all the employees who helped us for making a memorable anniversary. We will definitely be back to The Pink Door on our next anniversary...

I stopped by for dinner around 8 PM. The place was bustling, with only two servers handling the crowd. I had to wait between 5 to 10 minutes before being seated. Having done my research, I promptly ordered the Mala Spicy Beef Dry Mix, a popular choice among Yelpers. Biang Biang specializes in hand-pulled noodles, known as lamian in Chinese. These noodles are made by repeatedly stretching and folding a piece of soft wheat dough to align the gluten and warm it up. The dough is then rolled out to a workable thickness and cut into portions.The food arrived quickly. Despite being called "dry," the dish wasn't completely dry like Hakka noodles, which is something to keep in mind if you're new to the restaurant. Unlike some Chinese/Vietnamese dishes that might include broth with animal bone marrow or blood, this dry order didn't contain any such elements.The Mala Spicy Beef Dry Mix was delicious and perfectly spiced (I ordered medium spicy). The portion was generous. Despite needing to ask for a fork (I know, sacrilege), I wasted no time digging in.The table service was adequate but not proactive. I had to flag down my server once for the fork and later for a glass of water, both of which were brought promptly.Finding parking in the area can be difficult and expensive. It cost me $6 for an hour of street parking several blocks away from the restaurant.The seating area is not huge, but the tables more closely spaced than in a traditional American restaurant. There appeared to be a flight of stairs leading to an upper level, but I didn't see anyone using it.The prices are competitive, reflecting Seattle's pricey food scene. Overall, I'd not hesitate to return.

Inventive food. Warm, community-creating environment. Honest, work-their-a**es-off owners and staff. One of my favorite Nue memories has been joining their One-World dinner featuring Syria. Not only were we exposed to delicious food (which, of course, we'd never tried before), but we dined with several Syrians, many of whom were recent refugees. It felt more like someone's home than a restaurant. Thanks, Nue, for enabling me to break (damn good) bread with people I never would have otherwise had the chance to meet.

Nue is hands down one of my favorite restaurants in Seattle. It's vibey, and the food is delicious, unique, and colorful. The cocktail menu is fun too. Also, don't forget to try the Thai water beetles!

I love Nue and I really mean it. The food is amazing and of awesome quality but, most importantly, it's such a cozy place! On the other note, we had a first date with my future husband there so it will always have a special place in my heart

Nue is a unique restaurant in Seattle, and it's worth a trip to Capitol Hill from the 'burbs if you haven't already tried it. It's a small, locally-owned business and the owners travel the world to find new and delicious international street food dishes for their menu, so there's often something new to discover. I'm not an adventurous eater but my husband is, and there's always something there for both of us.The dining room is an intimate setting with decor sourced from all over. Great date-night place in a classy, relaxed setting with international flair. It's also been fun to see it featured on several food TV shows!

This place has such a great variety of food from all cultures! I recommend doing family style so that you can try a bunch of different things because everything is delicious! Don't forget to get the tower of wings!!!
One of the few restaurants where you will not be disappointed when you are adventurous

Even though one of the things I tasted was a giant bug, this is one of the best places to eat in Seattle! It's like taking a round-the-world tour with someone who's crazy about food. The laphet toke and the Chengdu wings remain favorites of ours. The UN skewers were awesome, especially accompanied by the pineapple cornbread. Their house made ice creams are mind blowing too. The water bugs...well, there was a crazy story that goes along with them, that we were lucky enough to hear firsthand from Chris.

I've dined now at Nue twice, and was floored by everything I tried. Having been to many of the countries represented on the menu, I was ready to be disappointed but was impressed by the combination of authenticity and creative spin placed on the food. While I agree it helps to be adventurous (part of the fun eating here), the food is surprisingly accessible. Somewhat randomly, I ended up on a rafting trip on a 4 day rafting trip with Chris Cvetkovich, who owns Nue along with his wife Uyen. We somehow conned Chris to cook for us the entire trip - it was incredible to see him come up with exquisite meals riverside, often improvising with random ingredients from various coolers. More impressive was hearing Chris talk passionately about the people, places, and food he has encountered across the world. Inspiring. I'll be heading back to Nue for the food, but will enjoy it in a new light after spending time with Chris

I don't eat a lot of meat but when I have a fried chicken craving this is the spot for the best wings I have ever had. The presentation on the wings is awe-striking as you are served a massive tower of perfectly golden brown wings. The wings have the perfect amount of flavor and a mouth watering crunch when you bite into them. If you're looking for a lighter accompaniment to your wings, the Brussel sprouts with coconut are delightful. The negative to the restaurant is it is smaller so it can feel cramped. I wish the tables were a little more spread out and there was better sound dampening. That said it's in Seattle, and I'm sure they've done they best they can in order to make a profit. I highly recommend this place as the top spot for wings in the state. Not only that but they also have a really unique menu with other delicious items.
Went for brunch and was blown away. Was absolutely delicious. Will come back again and again.

Other than that, it's fab!

Excellent, unique foods. A sampler of the best food around the world. It is highly unlikely that you have eaten anything that is on the menu. Come willing to try new things. We suggest ordering multiple items and sharing them family style.

I'm not exactly what you'd call a "Professional Yelper" (this is my first review) but this was seriously the BEST meal I've had in years!I started with the Syrian Kale Salad and Tostilocos. The salad was dressed perfectly and the crunch of the toasted almonds and sweetness of the 'shattered dates' (I still need to figure out how they cut them so damn small) were the perfect textural and flavor counterbalance to the dressing.The Tostilocos were really cool and from what I was told, a pretty common Street Food in Mexico. They consisted of a bag of Mexican, Salsa Verde Tostitos, slit open and stuffed with all kinds of flavors and textures that just worked. Hot sauce, crunchy jicama and cucumber, Tamarind candy, nuts, pickled pork skins, etc. Super fun.I then, based on everyone's suggestions on Yelp, had the goat curry. This dish was over the top, or is it 'off the hook'? I can never keep up with these things. Anyway, super complex dish, just the perfect amount of spicy heat and the sweetness of the coconut cornbread on the side was the bomb (or is it the 'shit'?) I had the McNguyen cocktail which was Vietnamese coffee and Irish Jameson Whiskey shaken over ice. This was one of those drinks that could get a pass just for the clever name but OMG the flavor combo was amazeballs. I'd never tried Vietnamese coffee before, and now need to without whiskey, just to taste the pure flavor of it. After that I need to move back to the one with Jameson though because the combo was fantastic.......and I love whiskeyI was totally full by now but wanted to try their liquid nitrogen ice cream I'd heard about and ordered the French Toast and Bacon Flavor. Without going into too much detail let's just say I'm stopping by after work tomorrow just for another scoop.The service was fantastic and the decor super unique and kitschy but didn't feel contrived. I've been to a lot of bars and restaurants that just hang a couple of taxidermy pieces on the wall wearing hats and call it cool but this place definitely has its own character but still feels real (esp for Capitol Hill)I got a chance to chat a lot with one of the owners (he was my waiter) who mentioned that a lot of stuff on the menu changes all the time. Can't wait to come back and see what's new!!

Toulouse Petit is a Louisiana restaurant that offers a unique brunch experience with delicious southern flavors incorporated into its food. The food is consistently tasty, and you can tell that a lot of care and attention is put into the preparation of each dish. The menu is varied, and there are plenty of options to choose from, including some creative twists on classic brunch items.However, one downside is that the coffee leaves much to be desired. If you're a coffee lover, you might be disappointed with the quality of the coffee here. The only downside is the wait time, but that's just a testament to how popular and beloved this spot is.
